question_metadata.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?

responses_by_article.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Value-based pricing orientation → helps secure sustainable revenue through high quality SaaS software
Targeting broad markets → achieve economies of scale necessary for survival
Expanding client base continuously → leverage economies of scale
Usage-based pricing strategies → reflect both vendors' costs to deliver and clients' costs to consume services
Steadily improving service quality → retain sizeable pool of clients
Pricing aligned with client value perception → maximize business value for clients
Flexible payment options with bulk discounts → alleviate financial pressure and encourage prepayment
Accommodating diverse client preferences through multiple pricing components → collect extra revenue from customized requirements
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 5: 'SaaS vendors seem to prefer value-based to cost-based orientation in software pricing. Value is what clients really want to pay for. For SaaS vendors, the focus on value-based orientation in software pricing will help them in securing sustainable revenue through the offering of high quality SaaS software' | Page 5-6: 'SaaS vendors tend to target broad markets to gain economy of scale...To survive and thrive, vendors are supposed to expand clients base continuously in order to leverage on economy of scale' | Page 2: 'SaaS vendors are hence compelled to steadily improve service quality and price it accordingly in order to retain a sizeable pool of clients and achieve economies of scale' | Page 6: 'usage-based pricing strategies were popular among SaaS vendors because usage-based metrics reflect both vendors' costs to deliver services and clients' costs to consume services' | Page 3: 'Payment-based pricing benefits clients by granting them more payment freedom' | Page 5: 'Adopting pricing components from different categories could help in accommodating diverse client preferences...some SaaS vendors included pricing components from different categories in their pricing strategies might demonstrate their endeavor to collect extra revenue by targeting clients with customized requirements'

responses_by_article.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Customer-driven model selection → Appropriate revenue and pricing models aligned with customer needs → Market acceptance and adoption
Flexible pricing strategies (user-based, time-based, version-based, bundling) → Increased service attractiveness → Higher customer acquisition
Lower production costs through public cloud → Cost savings in delivery and maintenance → Competitive pricing advantage
Multi-tenant/multi-instance architecture → Efficient resource utilization → Ability to serve both rental and licensing models
Protection against low switching costs (time-based pricing for pure-SaaS, labor-intensive implementation for enterprise-SaaS) → Customer retention → Sustainable revenue
Ability to offer both rental and licensing models → Meet diverse customer security and IT infrastructure needs → Avoid losing customers with specific requirements
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 6: 'It can be concluded that customers or delivery channels are the main driving force to the selection of the most appropriate pricing and revenue model in the market' | Page 5: 'software firms can use flexible revenue and pricing strategies to make the service more attractive for customers' | Page 5: 'The rental model through the public cloud decreased the production costs of case firms... made it possible to offer the software at a lower price' | Page 5: 'Pure-SaaS providers (Firms A and B) seem to use time-based price discrimination to protect their business against low switching costs... enterprise-SaaS providers (Firms C and D) seem to protect their business against low switching costs by using separate pricing for the implementation work'

responses_by_article.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Organizational preparedness → Deep understanding and ability to implement decisions throughout the value chain
Hybrid model approach → Smoother transition by maintaining both SaaS and on-premise products, buying time for development without sacrificing market share
Controlled transition → Pilot implementation with approved customers to minimize negative effects and gain valuable feedback
Partner collaboration (hand-in-hand approach) → Maintaining ecosystem stability by helping partners adapt their business models
Balanced R&D allocation → 50% each for SaaS and on-premise products to maintain quality on both ends
Managing the whole ecosystem → Taking full consideration of inter-dependencies among stakeholders prevents ecosystem collapse
Aligned KPIs → Performance indicators that support rather than conflict with the transition strategy
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 7, Section 6.2: 'I believe one of the most critical success factors are what you can call organizational preparedness, since this goes so deep in our ability to understand and implement decisions throughout the value chain.' | Page 7, Section 6.2: 'The later adjustment to a "hybrid strategy" led to smoother transition process, as keeping and maintaining on-premise products 1) buys more time for developing new SaaS products without sacrificing existing marketing share due to lack of finished products to sell, and 2) provides a chance for both the customers and partners to gradually adapt to the change.' | Page 6, Section 5.2.2: 'ERP Co conducted a round of pilot implementation by selling 50 SaaS product to approved customers who met the criteria for SaaS implementation... Doing so, ERP Co has gained valuable feedback from the customers for further development and improvement of the SaaS product' | Page 7, Section 5.2.2: 'The strategy is to go "hand in hand" with partners to make the transition.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Managing a Software Business
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Developer productivity as number-one priority → Enables great software creation
Choice of open file formats, APIs, and plug-in mechanisms → Can make difference between failure and success in platform strategy
Network effects and hub positioning → Remarkably rewarding in winner-takes-all field
Low marginal distribution cost → Additional sales translate into pure profit
Managing sensible choices and prioritization → Handles trade-offs between features and quality attributes
Constant investment in software evolution → Prevents software from becoming obsolete
Motivation, empowerment, and trust of developers → Effective management of knowledge workers
Separate engineering career track → Retains stellar developers instead of promoting them to mediocre managers
Continuous process improvement → Ensures effectiveness and efficiency
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 4, Section 'Your Processes': 'Keeping developers productive should be your number-one priority. Eliminate distractions and waste, give them all the tools and hardware they need, and set up your organization's structures in a way that lets them write great software.' | Page 2: 'The choice of open or proprietary file formats, APIs, and plug-in mechanisms can make the difference between failure and success.' | Page 2: 'Positioning yourself as a hub in a winner-takes-all field can be remarkably rewarding.' | Page 3: 'It's your job as a manager to make sensible choices, triage, prioritize, and handle expectations.' | Page 3: 'unless you constantly invest in your software, it will quickly become obsolete' | Page 4: 'Avoid promoting stellar developers to become mediocre managers, by having a separate engineering career track.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Digital sustainable business models: Using digital technology to integrate ecological sustainability into the core of business models
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Integration of ecological sustainability as core logic of organization → Creates both ecological and economic value
Digital technology enablement → Optimizes resources, creates knowledge, enables circularity, facilitates delivery and diffusion
Network effects → Attracts more customers, scales sustainable impact through ecosystem
Customer centricity strategy → Enables sustainable decision-making specific to individual customer needs
Breakthrough strategy → Offers sustainable alternatives to market-dominant products
Open BM strategy → Facilitates collaboration and value co-creation
Data analytics capabilities → Creates transparency and knowledge about sustainability performance
Multi-sided market orchestration → Enables value co-creation with complementors
Solidified business model → Start-ups between 4-10 years old with proven market establishment
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 10, Table 2: 'Customer centricity (27), Breakthrough (22), Open BM (14), Value network (12)' as differentiation strategies | Page 9: 'we found that the open BM strategy is used in approximately half of BMs with ubiquitous IT use' | Page 15, Table 4: Shows role of digital technology for each archetype | Page 13: 'Through the network effects in their ecosystems, the enablement of new sustainable BMs scales' | Page 19: 'start-ups valued at more than 1 billion US dollars, demonstrating that a lasting and successful establishment in the market is possible'

responses_by_article.article_title: When does a freemium business model lead to high performance? — A qualitative comparative analysis based on fuzzy Sets
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: High sensing capability → Perceives new opportunities, customer needs changes, competitor behavior → Achieves high performance
High seizing capability → Clear roles in acquiring resources/knowledge, learning from mistakes, obtaining quality resources at lower cost → Achieves high performance
High reconfiguring capability → Adjusts resource mix according to environmental changes, effective departmental collaboration, designs feasible solutions → Achieves high performance under uncertainty
Bundled freemium model + sensing capability → Critical combination even without other factors → Achieves high performance
Fragmented freemium model + all three dynamic capabilities → Under high environmental uncertainty → Achieves high performance
Network effects enhancement → Amplifies leader's advantage, increases user base and conversion rates → Higher profitability
Combination of bundled and fragmented models → Complementary relationship rather than substitution → Higher performance
Modular customization based on customer interests → Allows flexible upsells → Better value capture
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 11, Section 5.1: 'For companies with bundled and fragmented freemium business models, high sensing and seizing capabilities are critical to achieving high performance' | 'A high bundled freemium business model, high sensing capability, and a lack of fragmented freemium business models and seizing capability can lead to high performance, regardless of reconfiguration capabilities and environmental uncertainty' | 'Under high environmental uncertainty, offering fragmented freemium business models with or without a bundled freemium business model will lead to high performance if they have high sensing, seizing, and reconfiguring capabilities' | Page 3: 'enhanced network effects amplify the leader's advantage over followers, increasing the user base and increasing conversion rates'

Cloud infrastructure partnerships → Scalability

Experienced management team → Provides tacit knowledge for global scaling

responses_by_article.article_title: Toward Building Specialized Information Systems as Software Platforms
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Combinatorial Innovation → Enables third parties to build on top of platform
Ecosystem Enablers → Surrounds platform with ecosystem of partners and developer tools
Data Democratization → Makes data accessible to third parties through APIs
Platform thinking mindset → Enables business transformation
Organizational culture adaptation → Embraces platform thinking mindset
Common architecture principles → Aligns different teams within organization
Platform team → Responsible for enabling platform business model
Ecosystem of partners and developers → Necessary for platform success
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 4: '1) Combinatorial Innovation: a platform enables combinatorial innovation by allowing third parties to build on top of it. This is done by providing an open and well-documented API that third parties can use to develop their own products and services' | Page 4: '2) Ecosystem Enablers: A platform surrounds itself with an ecosystem of partners, developer tools, and other services that make it easy for third parties to develop products and services that work with the platform' | Page 4: '3) Data Democratization: A platform democratizes access to data by making it easy for third parties to access and use data from the platform' | Page 2: '1) Platform thinking mindset is key to enable the business transformation' | Page 2: '2) The organizational culture needs to be adapted to be able to embrace the platform thinking mindset' | Page 2: '3) A common set of architecture principles is critical to align different teams within the organization' | Page 2: '4) A platform team that is responsible for enabling the platform business model is essential' | Page 2: 'An ecosystem of partners and developers is necessary for the success of the platform'

responses_by_article.article_title: E-business evolution: an analysis of mobile applications' business models
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Efficiency (fast, bug-free performance) → Higher positive reviews. Lock-in (fun, user interaction) → Higher positive reviews. App design (graphics, controls, ease of use, content quality) → Higher positive reviews (57.8% of comments, most significant factor). Design of app monetization (quality of in-app purchases, non-intrusive ads) → Higher positive reviews. Content-based app typology → 80-91.6% of successful apps. Mixed value capture mechanisms → 69% of pay per download apps.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 10: 'Among all the seven sources of value, complementarities (p= 0.67), novelty (p= 0.95) and developer behaviour (p= 0.12) are not statistically significant, while efficiency, lock-in, design, and the design of app monetisation are statistically significant (p< 0.05); these are the significant predictors for positive reviews' | Page 10: 'app design received the vast majority of comments (i.e. 57.8%) among all sources of value; more in depth, the ease of use and the quality and quantity of contents have been the two major codes detected –respectively with 19.7% and 25.9%' | Page 14: 'content apps, whose value is driven by their efficiency, lock-in, design, and ability to add complementary monetisation mechanisms (i.e. In-App purchases) beside the ads value capture schema (or 'mixed' for 'pay per download' apps), are the ones that can survive digital Darwinism'

Technical staff availability → Successful deployment

responses_by_article.article_title: Making a Business Out of (Predictive Application Management in) the Fog
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Being first to market → establish strong brand recognition and customer loyalty before competitors enter
Being first to market → improve service and set market price before others do
Strong branding process → create switching costs for customers evaluating competitors
Top of the range quality services → create switching costs along with lock-in strategies
Reliable state-of-art predictive methodologies continuously improved → successfully offer competitive service
Skilled and expert R&D personnel → develop new prototype and production functionalities
Third-party independence → produce more accurate results from different hardware/infrastructures data
Third-party trusted intermediary position → large companies trust more than disclosing data to direct competitors
Data collection from Infrastructure Providers → increase quality of predictive results
Strategic partnerships with Infrastructure Providers → fundamental for monitoring and data feeding
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3: 'It is therefore important for a company which aims at selling predictive Fog application management to start a consistent branding process as soon as possible, whilst providing top of the range quality for their services. This, along with suitable lock-in strategies, would create costs for customers evaluating a switch to a competitor. Usually, being among the firsts on the market enables a company to establish strong brand recognition and customer loyalty before other competitors enter the arena [35]. It also permits to improve the service and to set the market price for the new offer before others do' | Page 6: 'A set of reliable state-of-art predictive methodologies, continuously improved and extended, is key to successfully offer and deliver a competitive service (Key resources). The business we foresee should rely on skilled and expert personnel taking care of research and development of new prototype and production functionalities' | Page 4: 'a third-party provider for predictive application management can base its analyses on data collected from different hardware or infrastructures and produce more accurate (and satisfying) results. Large established companies might trust more such new provider as an intermediary, with respect to disclosing data to their direct competitors' | Page 4: 'Differently from Application Operators, they can pay for the service they use also in terms of data collected during actual application management in order for the company selling predictive solutions to increase the quality of their results' | Page 6: 'their partnership represents a fundamental strategic alliance with non-competitors as they have to run a monitoring service on top of their infrastructures to feed data to the prediction engine'

responses_by_article.article_title: Analysis of Freemium Business Model Considering Network Externalities and Consumer Uncertainty
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: High true value of software → Higher profit and more likely to choose freemium model
Strong network effect → Freemium generates higher profit, customer welfare, and social welfare
Significant customer underestimation of value → Freemium outperforms charge-for-everything model
Optimal free content decision (not too much) → Avoids excessive cannibalization effect
Quality free app offering → Boosts sales of paid app
Strong functional fit between free and premium services → Increases user conversion probability
Large user base attracted by free version → Generates network effects that improve premium value

Prior experience with related technologies (service-oriented architectures, agile development) → faster adaptation

responses_by_article.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Organizational preparedness → ability to understand and implement decisions throughout value chain
Hybrid model (balanced approach to SaaS and on-premise) → smooth transition, maintains product quality, provides adaptation time for customers and partners
Controlled transition with pilot implementations → minimizes negative effects, gains valuable customer feedback, eases customers into change
Hand-in-hand partnership strategy → maintains ecosystem stability, supports partner adaptation, prevents ecosystem collapse
Proper ecosystem management → taking inter-dependencies among stakeholders into full consideration
Aligning KPIs with transition goals → ensures organizational motivation and proper incentives
Matched changes across business areas → revenue management, sales channels, customer support all adapted together
Partner compensation mechanisms → higher percentages of subscription fees initially to help partners adapt
Maintaining existing customer relationships → continued support for on-premise products during transition

responses_by_article.article_title: Business models and opportunity creation: How IT entrepreneurs create and develop business models under uncertainty
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Ability to reassess and pivot business model when infrastructure technology limitations discovered → enabled survival when 3G networks proved inadequate
Finding alternative infrastructure technologies (IPTV, Internet) → expanded addressable market when original 3G plan failed
Revenue sharing model → enabled market entry without upfront investments in difficult financial times (post-IT bubble)
Demonstrating value to all partners (game publishers, operators, complementary providers) → secured participation from key ecosystem actors
Building valuable partnerships to access resources otherwise unattainable → gained content, marketing channels, credibility through partners
Product development integrating component technologies → reduced dependency on third parties, easier to sell (Model 3)
Providing SDK to game developers → enabled rapid game publication, saved porting resources
Patience and persistence → maintained original idea over 14 years despite being 'over ten years ahead of its time'
Attracting credible investors and well-known partners → received funding from Intel Capital, NTT, Orange; contracts with Disney, Ubisoft, Warner Bros
Expanding to cloud console → overcame limitation of being tied solely to IPTV infrastructure

responses_by_article.article_title: Business Models for Cloud Computing: Experiences from Developing Modeling & Simulation as a Service Applications in Industry
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Simplified customer interface (one-stop-shops and AppCenter) → enables user identification and charging. Single point of charging → avoids complex point-to-point relationships with multiple stakeholders. Flexible business model options → accommodates different stakeholder needs and market segments. Multi-cloud support → provides flexibility and cost optimization. Strong stakeholder partnerships → ensures business benefits for all participants. Platform scalability → handles varying workload demands. Customer support at appropriate levels → maintains user satisfaction. Revenue distribution mechanisms → ensures fair compensation across value chain. Market segmentation → addresses heterogeneous manufacturing and engineering markets. Technology abstraction → hides cloud complexity from end-users.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 8: 'What is common to all the business models discussed in this paper is the need to collect revenue based on both platform and infrastructure use. In some ways this reinforced the need for an identified entry point to the MSaaS application to enable end-users to be identified and then to be charged on an appropriate basis...This partially motivated the development of the one-stop-shop application specific portals and the general AppCenter' | Page 5: 'The business venture is based on close partnership and collaboration amongst a number of key stakeholders' | Page 7: 'The benefit to the end-user is potentially cheaper, more accessible simulation technologies' | Page 8: 'this both simplifies charging mechanisms and enables end-users to be presented with a single point of charging rather than point-to-point relationships with the many stakeholders'

responses_by_article.article_title: Towards a better Understanding of the Dynamics of Platform as a Service Business Models
responses_by_article.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Core value proposition → Direct impact on CVP
Governance model → Affects CVP attractiveness
Technical scope → Influences CVP positively
Additional services → Strengthens CVP over time
Platform improvements → Enhances CVP through new capabilities
Market penetration → Supports CVP through brand image and reputation
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 4, Section 5.3: 'We identified six factors influencing the CVP positively: (1.) PaaS offers differ notably in their core value proposition which has a direct impact on the corresponding CVP. (2.) Which governance model a PaaS provider is using affects the CVP. For instance, presumably an open governance model is more attractive for potential customers. The next two features (3.) technical scope and (4.) additional services both influence the CVP positively and will gain strength over time through platform improvements. (5.) the platform improvements itself improve the CVP, through capabilities not considered in other influence factors. And finally (6.), the market penetration in the form of a company's brand image and reputation supports the CVP'
